Driven by the belief that everyone deserves access to opportunities, we dedicate ourselves to giving back to our communities. Through engaging seminars and workshops, we create a platform for sharing experiences and insights, fostering an inclusive environment where every voice is valued. What sets us apart is our commitment to volunteerism. Every member of our club contributes their time and expertise to make a positive impact. We believe in the power of meaningful connections and the transformative potential of education, especially during the pivotal high school to university transition. clubs.name: University College Dragon Boat Club (UCDBC)
clubs.description: UCDBC is a dragon boat racing club founded on passion, drive, and resilience. As one of the fastest university teams in Canada across the mixed, open, and women’s divisions, we take pride in fostering a welcoming environment that promotes personal growth and development. We welcome athletes of all skill levels and experience—whether you’re a seasoned paddler or brand new to the sport, there’s a place for you at UCDBC. We are committed to training athletes with equal dedication, helping each individual reach their potential while providing a supportive community to build meaningful friendships. We compete in several regattas during the summer, with our most recent success being the defense of our title as 1st place in the U24 Open division, our 1st gold medal in the U24 Women’s division, and a bronze in the U24 Mixed division at the Canadian National Championships. Additionally, our performance at the international level at the Club Crew World Championships (Ravenna, Italy) earned us 6 out of 9 gold medals across the U24 Open (3/3 gold), Women’s (1/3 gold), and Mixed divisions (2/3 gold), securing our position as the top U24 club in the world. Looking to get started at the gym? During the school year, we provide trainers to help you get stronger and reach your fitness goals. Beyond training, we host a variety of social events and gatherings, as we highly value team bonding. Outside of the team, we actively promote the sport of dragon boat, organize fundraising events, and encourage fitness within our local community. Our goal is to continue excelling as a top-performing dragon boat team, while helping our athletes become the best version of themselves, both in and out of the boat. We hope you’ll join us on this journey. Make Waves. Make History. We wish to acknowledge this land on which the University of Toronto operates. clubs.name: University College United Survivors (UCUS)
clubs.description: The mission of the University College branch of The PEARS Project at the University of Toronto is to provide support and resources to survivors of gender-based and sexual violence. Our areas of work include social advocacy, mental health advocacy, social justice, sexual health awareness, and activism. As a grassroots, trauma-informed coalition founded and led by survivors, PEARS values survivors as leaders whose voices are essential for driving policy change. By establishing a survivor-led community and resource network, PEARS aims to enhance access to legal, mental health, and capacity-building supports. Collaborating with college branches allows PEARS to foster relationships with broader student communities and promote the efforts of other campus stakeholders. clubs.name: University of Toronto Accessibility Awareness Club
clubs.description: U-TAAC : The voice of students with disabilities since 2021. We host discussions about disability issues in an educational and safe environment for students to share experiences and form connections with the disability community. We facilitate conversations of accessibility between the student body and various branches of Student Life and the University, and offer a disability perspective on several projects. An accessibility club that fosters monthly discussion about disability issues and aims to spread awareness. Our members are students who are both non-registered and registered with Accessibility Services. There are many disability-related clubs and councils out there. But each of them tends to focus on one disability and does not provide students with the chance to form a community, share personal experiences, or a space to educate those who do not have a disability. We aim to fix that by opening our club to more than one type of disability, so that students, with or without disabilities, can express their own experiences, hear from others’ experiences, and learn. clubs.name: University of Toronto Allegro Student Choir
clubs.description: Hello and welcome to the Student Organization Portal (SOP) website of the University of Toronto Allegro Choir! We are a student-led choir that specializes in singing Mandarin and English songs, bringing together different cultures through the universal language of music. Music is an essential part of any culture, reflecting and shaping societal values and emotions. From the enchanting melodies of traditional Beijing operas to the heartwarming strains of native Taiwanese folk songs, and from the passionate expressions of English Romanticism to the soulful tunes of American country rock, music has the power to connect us all. In today’s rapidly evolving world, where technology often reduces face-to-face interaction, Allegro Choir strives to revive this crucial form of communication. By performing songs that represent Chinese and other cultures, we hope to engage with and celebrate the diverse communities that make up our global society. Since our humble beginnings as a student-led club in 2007, Allegro Choir has grown into a semi-professional ensemble, delighting audiences with our captivating performances. This school year, we will continue our weekly rehearsals and plan to perform at numerous events, culminating in our highly anticipated annual year-end concert. The Allegro Choir is not only about making music; it’s also a supportive and inclusive environment where music enthusiasts can learn new skills, forge life-long friendships, and create cherished memories. We invite all U of T students with a passion for singing and an interest in learning Chinese to join our musical family. Stay tuned to this website and our social media platforms for updates on our performances, behind-the-scenes glimpses, and more exciting news about the University of Toronto Allegro Choir! Happy singing! We wish to acknowledge this land on which the University of Toronto operates. clubs.name: University of Toronto Autonomous Drone Racing Student Team (UTADR)
clubs.description: University of Toronto Autonomous Drone Racing Team (UTADR) is a passionate group of roboticists, drone enthusiasts, consisting both graduate and undergraduate engineering students. Our mission is to innovate and lead in the world of autonomous drone racing using cutting-edge AI technologies. We focus on developing first-person-view (FPV) drones equipped with onboard sensors and computers, designed to autonomously navigate complex environments and race through gates in record time. This challenge demands the integration of advanced AI-driven perception, localization, planning, and control algorithms. Our team competes in international autonomous drone racing competitions and contributes to the scientific community by publishing research papers in top-tier journals and conferences. UTADR operates at the Flight System & Control Lab (FSC) and the Learning Systems and Robotics Lab (LSY), the University of Toronto Institute of Aerospace Studies (UTIAS) MarsDome, Myhal Centre for Engineering Innovation and Entrepreneurship, using facilities such as the motion capture system, 3D printers, and GPU clusters. We are committed to fostering a community of students with a shared interest in autonomous drones. By joining UTADR, you’ll engage in hands-on projects, collaborate with experts in the field, and help push the boundaries of AI and drone technology. Whether you’re new to drone racing or an experienced enthusiast, we welcome you to be a part of this exciting journey. We wish to acknowledge this land on which the University of Toronto operates. clubs.name: University of Toronto Autonomous Scale Racing Club
clubs.description: With an aim to learn how humans learn to drive and develop better learning based algorithms, and bringing more fun to students and faculties, we bring the adrenaline of RC car racing to UofT, hosting practice runs/races monthly/bi-monthly. At the other times, we work on autonomous driving projects using cutting edge learning based perception methods(such as NERF-SLAM or Gaussian-Splatting-SLAM), and state of the art models for control (such as the Dreamer v3 algorithm), evaluating these on our vision and IMU based RC race car, aiming to be able to compete with professional human competitors. Having research experience/relevant course works on robot perception/state estimation/neural networks and deep learning can be very helpful. Please feel free to join if you’re just looking for a new hobby or being involved in a super cool side project. DM us at scale_uoft on Instagram if you’re interested in contributing/getting involved. clubs.name: University of Toronto Baja Racing Student Team (UTBR)
clubs.description: UofT Baja Racing (UTBR) is a multidisciplinary student design team for the adventurous spirit and mud enthusiast. We aim to build community connections and encourage hands-on learning through the exciting process of designing, manufacturing, and presenting a 4WD vehicle for exciting and treacherous terrains. Each year, our team competes in international competitions, where we push our vehicle’s capabilities through different challenges. We emphasize both the engineering technical and business aspects of preparing a vehicle for static events like design reports, sales presentations and cost analysis as well as dynamic events that test the endurance, acceleration, and maneuverability of the vehicle. As the only team at UofT working on off-road vehicles with an internal combustion engine, we offer a unique opportunity to explore a niche area of engineering that’s both a challenge and edge-of-the-Baja seat thrilling. We’re not just about building cars; we’re about building a community of creative problem-solvers, passionate innovators and adrenaline nuts. clubs.name: University of Toronto Buddha’s Light Club
clubs.description:
Introduction: The University of Toronto Buddha’s Light Club seeks to provide U of T students with the opportunity to meet regularly in a supportive group setting to practice meditation, discuss Humanistic Buddhism, and develop friendships. There is a profound need for all of us to maintain a balance between the mind and the body. We believe we can help all Chinese students in the following ways:
• Deal with stress and other negative states of mind in a productive manner.
• Learn about our negative states of mind through the lens of Buddhist teachings and practices.
• Foster compassion, loving joy, and equanimity in our daily lives. Objectives: • To promote Humanistic Buddhism.
• To encourage students to say good words, think good thoughts, do good deeds. All in all, to apply the Three Goods in daily life. Events: • Culture: To promote Humanistic Buddhism; to promote traditional Chinese culture by hosting international student dinner during Chinese New Year.
• Education: To 1) organize Dhamma talks by inviting Venerable from Fo Guang Shan Temple, 2) attend Buddhist Youth College at Fo Guang Shan temple to learn about Dhamma, meditation and Buddhist ritual, and 3) participate regional and world Buddhist Youth conferences.
• Charity: We organize blood donation events with Canadian Blood Service and Senior visiting program with the Toronto Intergenerational Partnership.
• Cultivation: Field trip to the temple; Volunteering in the temple; chanting; transcribing of the sutras. Through the ongoing activities and practices, students can bring positive changes in society, purify the minds of the many, and make a small contribution on behalf of Buddhism for our world, countries and society. clubs.description: Hello there! Interested in cooking with the most beautiful cookware of all time? Join the UofT Cast Iron Cooking Club (UofT CICC) where you will learn everything about cast iron cookware! We will teach you everything from how to care for it (seasoning, washing, restoring, storage) and to learning how to cook with it! Cast iron skillets are a fantastic cookware that will last basically your entire life with the right care, and can even be restored if rusted. They are also THE optimal cookware for cooking meats like steak, pork chops, and ground beef. It can even be used to bake foods like paratha and cornbread, or make some bomb kimchi fried rice. You can use it for basically anything. At Uoft CICC, you will learn all about awesome recipes you can make in a simple cast iron skillet that will be sent out in newsletters, can join workshops to learn how to season your cast iron, tips for general cooking, and much more! By the end of the year you will know how to cook the most juiciest, flamboyant, mind-blowing steak that will blow your friends’ minds. We can also accommodate for people of any dietary needs, just let us know when you sign up with us and we will adjust what recipes we send out! Whether you own a cast iron, are interested in getting one, or simply want to join for the ride, you are highly encouraged to join! We only want to spread the awesomeness of cast iron cooking. Finance, a key component of the economic system, ensures the proper flow and allocation of funds, fostering business growth and innovation. Although the University of Toronto ranks highly in global economic and business disciplines, its students have relatively weak networks in China’s finance and economics sectors. UTCFEA aims to build a broad and tight-knit network of finance and economic talent, providing career and academic opportunities to bridge this gap. The association embraces “merchant guild” culture and collaborates with University of Toronto alumni to offer experience sharing and career guidance. We are committed to creating a sustainable community that cultivates future leaders and innovators. UTCFEA values the dignity of labor and the spirit of innovation, opposes malicious competition, and recruits new members through invitation and recommendation. The program is available during the academic school year (from September to June), providing the following services: The program matches high school students with mentors who are current University of Toronto students or university graduates. clubs.name: University of Toronto Mental Health Student Association (UofTMHA)
clubs.description: The purpose of this not-for-profit student-run association is to break the stigma surrounding mental health and empower students through their mental health journeys while also practicing diversity, equity & inclusion. We strive to educate and promote healthy coping mechanisms among students struggling with their mental health and aim to make mental health resources a lot more accessible to students. We aim to do this by hosting events, seminars, workshops, fundraisers, and other initiatives throughout the year to raise awareness and educate UofT students as well as members of the community on various mental health themes. In our approach, we aim to increase representations of various mental health topics and amplify voices of underrepresented groups within the university space online and in-person while constantly obtaining ongoing feedback from club members and the UofT community to better cater our initiatives towards their needs. competing at the highest level nationally across Canada. This dynamic team is divided into two teams, each with a shared commitment to excellence in the world of mock trial competitions. clubs.name: University of Toronto Mississauga Chinese Academic and Professional Society  (UTMCAPS)
clubs.description: The mission of the Chinese Academic and Professional Society is to foster a thriving Chinese community that emphasizes academic and professional development. To achieve this mission, we will organize both in-person and online events designed to support the academic and professional growth of Chinese students at UTM. Our events will be categorized into internal and external activities. Internal events, exclusively for our members, aim to create a positive, academically and professionally oriented community where resources are exchanged, experiences are shared, and meaningful connections are developed. These will include networking events and seminars tailored for internal members. External events will be accessible to both internal and external members, aiming to disseminate general academic and professional opportunities available on and off campus, address common inquiries, and provide essential information to newly enrolled UTM students. Events such as subject-specific PoSt seminars and welcome ceremonies for first-year students will be part of this initiative. Beyond events, we will leverage social media and web platforms, producing posts, videos, and web pages to highlight academic and professional resources available to students. At UTMCE, we are committed to developing leadership skills in a supportive and collaborative environment , mastering innovative media strategies, and building a wide range of relationships in a diverse social environment. We empower our members personally and professionally through well-planned events and hands-on programs. Our Core Values:
– Leadership and Teamwork: Members work together in various departments and participate in event planning teams, which not only enhances teamwork, but also hones each member’s leadership skills.
– Media Creation and Application: Utilizing the power of social media and other digital platforms to assist members in developing effective communication skills, creating media highlights, and increasing social awareness.
– Personal Skills Development: Within the club, members have the opportunity to enhance a variety of personal skills by teaching each other and sharing experiences.
– An atmosphere of cooperation and learning: We focus on creating a relaxed and open environment where members can freely exchange ideas, solve problems together, and learn from each other’s experiences. By joining us, you will gain
– Opportunities to work on diverse and impactful projects, with real-world experience in teamwork and project management.
– Diversified skill development for future careers.
– Connecting to various resources and opportunities on and off campus. Participating in UTMCE is more than just joining a club, it’s the beginning of a new chapter in your overall development! clubs.name: University of Toronto Mississauga Pre-Medical Club (UTMPMC)
clubs.description: Are you interested in pursuing a career in the field of medicine? Join the University of Toronto Mississauga Pre-Medical Club, led by a diverse and collaborative team of students from both the UTSG and UTM campuses. We aim to provide information, resources, and guidance to students interested in pursuing medicine. Throughout the year, we invite healthcare professionals, medical students, and medical school advisors from across the globe to give our members a better insight into the field of medicine and the admissions process. We equip our members with all the right tools required to become competitive medical school applicants, such as mock MCAT exams administered under real timed-proctored conditions, multiple mini-interviews preparations, application support, general academic counselling, and much more. The UTMPMC is a positive environment in which students can network with like-minded individuals, and achieve access to work, volunteer and other valuable extracurricular opportunities. clubs.name: University of Toronto Mock Trial Club
clubs.description: The University of Toronto Mock Trial Club is the full realization of almost a decade of mock trial competition at UofT and the University of Toronto Pre-Law Students’ Association (UTPLSA). Host to Canada’s first, and most dominant, Canadian and American (AMTA) Mock Trial teams, including the first Canadian team to advance to the AMTA National Championship, the UofT Mock Trial Club is home to the most competitive mock trial programs in Canada. With dozens of competition wins, awards at the highest levels, and recognition for not just our competitive prowess but also civility, UofT Mock Trial is the perfect place to learn Mock Trial and compete with the best. Whether you’ve done mock trial before, or are totally new to the activity, we welcome everyone to come learn from the best competitors in Canada. clubs.name: University of Toronto Motorcycle Club (UTMC)
clubs.description: This club aims to provide access for University of Toronto students who are interested in motorcycles to learn about motorcycles. In the club, we will teach students how to ride motorcycles, how to maintain motorcycles and safe riding training. For students who are familiar with motorcycles, we provide a communication platform for motorcycle fans within the University of Toronto. At the same time, we will organize students with driving licenses and motorcycles to participate in group riding activities. We are also very interested in motorcycle racing. Our goal is to establish a closed-track motorcycle racing competition for higher education students in North America within 4 years from the founding of the club. We will also carry out motorcycle modification competitions every year to encourage students to try to design their own style of motorcycle. clubs.name: University of Toronto Portuguese Student Associations (UTPA)
clubs.description: Our club represents Portuguese and Portuguese-speaking students at the University of Toronto. Every year, the University of Toronto Portuguese Student Association (UTPA.), a group of students who are interested in Portuguese culture, encourages new Portuguese and Portuguese-speaking students (and all students) to come to the university to study. Our message is that young students of Lusophone can be whoever they would like to become. The UTPA is here to help them on their journey. We show students that university life does not have to be a lonely journey, but rather it can be an opportunity to meet new people, and to have new opportunities. We get involved in many outreach programs like Adopt-a-Student Day and our peer mentoring program, which allows 1st and 2nd-year students to be paired up with upper-year students who are available to guide them through their university journey. We also have a scholarship program every year for new students of Portuguese descent who come to the University to study. Our members are not all necessarily of Portuguese descent – some are Portuguese, most Luso-Canadian and others from other nationalities. Our only requirements to be a member are having an interest in the Portuguese culture, being a dedicated person, and being a team member. It is in the hands of our members to promote our message. Each member has the right to speak out. We have our Social Coordinators who plan events, discuss the details and plan out when, where, and how the event is to happen. Our secretary stays in contact with other clubs, events, and news outlets and relays the information to the other group members. The secretary is also the person whom others contact if they want to apply for the scholarship or need specific information about our association. Our web designer designs our website and updates it with any news and upcoming events. Our Treasurer is responsible for our financial affairs. They control the expenses versus the profits and are responsible for working out our budgets for our events. The President and Vice-President are the contact people for specific problems or concerns that some may have. They are the people who decide the positions and have the right to decide who is committed and responsible and who is fulfilling their tasks. They are also responsible for getting the club’s recognition and any specific campus rights they may require. Above all, all of our members are students themselves, so we have to balance our duties and schedules, which is not an easy task. We are all friends, and we enjoy being part of a small but growing group. Many other students are aware of us and get involved during an event but decide that they do not have the time to attend the meetings of the UTPA. For the members who are part of the UTPA, it is a comfortable and fun environment. It is a chance to make new friends and to plan and develop new contacts. We celebrate the end of every UTPA year with a scholarship dinner, our “Primavera Gala,” at which we reward our Luso-Canadian scholarship winners who have been admitted to the University of Toronto. They are also featured in our annual magazine, “Origins,” which includes all of our events during that school year and news that may be important for anyone interested in joining. This year, the UTPA is hoping to have a fantastic year, one that we can make the founders and past members of the UTPA proud of. We will leave the constitution with a few words that one of our past members had expressed towards the UTPA: “In a school that is so big and where it seems that you are outnumbered, where everyone seems to be successful and where many times you feel lost, having a place to belong like the UTPA has made me comfortable and confident. It has made my university years much easier. Thank you, UTPA team.” I am a Luso-Portuguese, and I was a previous UTPA member. clubs.name: University of Toronto Shogi Club
clubs.description: Given the scarcity of Shogi players in English-speaking regions, we are establishing a Shogi club at the University of Toronto with three bold objectives in mind. Firstly, we plan to organize events to promote Shogi, initially within the university and subsequently throughout the city of Toronto. Secondly, we aim to develop an English-language website catering to novice Shogi players, addressing the current language barrier posed by the availability of resources predominantly in Japanese. Thirdly, we intend to conduct AI research on Shogi, leveraging the computer science knowledge of our members to apply and demonstrate the skills learned in class. Our ultimate goal is to popularize Shogi through various platforms and to advance AI research by utilizing the knowledge and skills acquired at the university, thus bridging the gap between this rich traditional game and the global, English-speaking community. clubs.name: University of Toronto Ski and Snowboard Club (UTSSC)
clubs.description:
The University of Toronto Ski and Snowboard Club (UTSSC) offers affordable opportunities for all students at the University of Toronto to participate in skiing and snowboarding adventures at both local and destination mountains. To make our club inclusive to everyone on campus, we have developed two exciting new programs, outlined below. In addition to ski trips across Canada, we host bi-monthly socials to offer additional bonding opportunities and to create a close-knit UTSSC family before the winter season starts. Our Programs: 1. The Mentorship Program: Experienced skiers and snowboarders teach beginners basic skills at extremely reduced costs and, in some cases, for free. Lessons are offered only on our Blue Mountain and Mont Tremblant trips, comprising about 35% of every trip.
2. The Safety and Wellness Program: This comprehensive division includes our Diversity and Inclusivity initiatives. The program establishes policies to ensure members are aware of their “Code of Conduct” responsibilities and creates a safe space for all. It focuses on recruiting a diverse membership, targeting various communities through specific advertising, and offering programs and scholarships that give back to the community. This division has two co-directors, one for each gender, to ensure everyone feels comfortable. We also have an anonymous complaint form for members to voice any concerns. Our Trips: Socials and Events:
UTSSC implements, when possible, a social director or events coordinator to arrange socials throughout the year with a small team, ensuring continuous engagement and bonding among members. Membership and Registration:
All information on how to register for memberships, trips, and socials can be found on our website: (http://www.utssc.com). UTSAP is non-denominational and inclusive of all self-defined non-organized paths and traditions focused on earth-based spirituality, including folk, polytheistic, nature-based, wiccan, pagan, and ancestral traditions and adversarial philosophies, such as a/theistic Satanism, Luciferianism, and Lilith worship. UTSAP seeks to welcome and reflect the diversity of the University of Toronto community in our membership and through our events. UTSAP also has the mission to engage with and educate the community about the wide array of pagan and folk spiritual traditions and concepts, and to promote inter-faith learning and cooperation. We strive to create a place where students have a community that aids their spiritual journey alongside their academics. clubs.description: Healing On Practice Education (H.O.P.E.) is dedicated to cultivating compassionate and skilled medical professionals in the Dominican Republic, fostering solidarity, and bridging healthcare gaps for equitable access. The missions are to educate and empower healthcare professionals to serve vulnerable communities, emphasizing humanization and friendly medical practice. U of T’s H.O.P.E will organize trips which will be planned by all participants. The trip will encompass two different settings: first, we will visit communities without access to medical care, providing essential services under the supervision of local doctors to ensure our efforts are impactful and sustainable. Second, participants will have the opportunity to shadow medical professionals in local hospitals, gaining experiences not available in Canada and developing a global health perspective. Additionally, all participants can request specific places to volunteer, such as orphanages, nursing homes, or communities for individuals with disabilities, tailoring the experience to their interests and ensuring a diverse impact. Join us in building a global network of empathetic healers dedicated to making a transformative impact on underserved communities! clubs.name: University of Toronto Student Chapter Global Medical Training

GMT organizes an annual trip for this purpose, granting university students interested in healthcare an opportunity to learn from local doctors and pharmacists at a level of medical residents’ experience. The trips teach students to treat patients despite cultural, language, and educational differences while respecting their autonomy and diversity. We hope students can recognize the detrimental impacts of underserved communities and be inspired to push more initiatives locally and internationally. Independent of the external organization, UofT GMT also develops and funds global crisis response initiatives and serves as a pre-medicine community for incoming students. Our mission involves cultivating deep engagement in seismic engineering through diverse Chapter activities. UT-EERI graduate members play a pivotal role by hosting academic and industrial guest lectures, mentoring the Undergraduate Seismic Design Competition (SDC) team, actively participating in the EERI community through volunteering, and advocating for enhanced comprehension of earthquakes’ impact on physical, social, economic, and political environments. clubs.name: University of Toronto Student Environmental Resource Network (UTERN)
clubs.description: The University of Toronto’s Environmental Resource Network (UTERN) is a levy organization that operates as a funding body and networking hub for any person, group or club within the university community interested in sustainability and environmentalism on campus. UTERN membership is open to all students, faculty, staff and alumni from any of the three campuses at the University of Toronto. To join our membership, join our http://utern.org/wp/mailing-list/. To facilitate an environmental network at U of T, UTERN hosts monthly Environmental Working Groups (EWGs), where the environmental community at U of T and beyond can pool their resources, share knowledge, and keep up to date on environmental initiatives across the U of T campuses. There are also EWGs at UTM and UTSC. UTERN also organizes EcoFEST, a two week long environmental and sustainability awareness campaign, as well as works with other campus groups for Sustainability Week. All full-time undergraduate students at UTSG, UTM, and UTSC as well as all full-time and part-time graduate students automatically pay the levy of $0.25/term, or $0.18/term for part-time to the student union. The levy supports student-led projects in relation to the environment for all of U of T, and is completely refundable for those unable, or unwilling, to pay. For more information on our levy, funding history, constitution, EWG meeting minutes, etc., visit our website. One of the primary goals of UTERN is to allocate funding to individuals or environmental groups planning projects or events related to sustainability. So this club is meant to provide a platform for small designers, models, artists, and photographers who want to start showcasing their work.
.UTFC provides an inclusive space and a friendly environment that allows like-minded people who enjoy fashion to come together to learn about the different fashion subcultures out there, and their progression throughout the years. This will not only enhance their academic and professional skills but also promote interdisciplinary collaboration and networking among students at different stages of their academic journey. clubs.name: University of Toronto Student’s Astronomy and Space Exploration Association (ASX)
clubs.description: The Astronomy & Space Exploration Association is a non-profit organization run by the University of Toronto space community, in Ontario, Canada. ASX’s purpose is to educate, excite, and inspire students, professionals, and the general public about astronomy and space. Since its inception in 2003, ASX has rapidly grown to over 1500 members, and has organized and hosted 10 or more events per year, attracting hundreds of event attendees each year. ASX’s signature event is the annual Symposium, which has attracted an audience of up to 500 people in a single event. Other events include the “Star Talk” Lecture Series, Panel Discussions, Space Exploration Showcase, and Observing Nights. Topics of discussion have covered various facets of space, such as ‘Mars and Beyond’, ‘The Search for Life’, ‘Cosmology from the Stratosphere’, and ‘Space Business’. Through our workshops, case competitions, and other events, students learn to assess real-world problems and solve them through innovative solutions. We also host several events that allow students to network with representatives from some of the top consulting firms, learn more about career paths, develop meaningful relationships, and break into the industry. While our organization continues to evolve over the years, we stand by our consistent goal of providing an accessible way to expand students’ horizons through a platform of exposure and opportunities. Our organization also manages a volunteer Consulting Group (CG) which matches top students with local non-profits and start-ups to solve current business problems. clubs.name: University of Toronto Students for a Free Iran (UTSFI)
clubs.description: The University of Toronto Students for a Free Iran (UTSFI) is an independent social organization that seeks to promote diversity and freedom for Iranians and Iranian-Canadians at the University of Toronto. UTSFI seeks to create a safe and inclusive space for the Iranian and Iranian-Canadian academic community to engage with and preserve the Iranian cultural and historical heritage. UTSFI acknowledges the unacceptable history of oppression based on gender, ethnicity, and religion in Iran. UTSFI has been formed to: (1) address this history of oppression, (2) preserve and document it, (3) and provide an open platform to the Iranian community to emerge as a free society from this history. UTSFI is non-partisan and non-religious. While aiming to promote freedom, equality, and liberty for the Iranian community, UTSFI will not advocate the interest of any political and/or religious entity. UTSFI is a non-profit organization. UTSFI will not provide services for the monetary benefit of any private entity and/or third-party organization. We wish to acknowledge this land on which the University of Toronto operates. clubs.name: University of Toronto Students Theatre Company (UTC)
clubs.description: As an ensemble, we will focus on a different dramatist and a different acting method such as Stella Adler, Grotowski stay Stanislavski. We will examine texts from Oscar Wilde, Shakespeare and other classical theatre writers. We put on the shows for training purposes and for the purpose of making showreels to step into the acting industry career.  We will coordinate show dates and workshops with dramatists, directors and actors in the theatre industry. There is a ten dollar membership fee which will be used to buy props and other necessary tools to run the club . We also do playwriting workshops which leads to a student written play being staged. This is a good opportunity for members to invite artistic directors to come and watch their shows to see their acting and their playwriting skills. These original plays will be chosen by votes from all of the members, Preferences are plays that will have enough characters for all of the club members to show their talents and skills. Meetings will be held regularly and members are expected to attend at least one of the two events each month and all of the rehearsals which will be scheduled after taking votes from all of the members. All of our performances will be recorded using a phone camera and will be shared with all of the members after gathering consent. This is a theatre company with a bright future, students will no longer have to wait four years to graduate in order to join an ensemble. University of Toronto will have its own theatre company which produces shows that its community wants and needs. We will learn the importance of team work in an ensemble, we will learn our own strengths and weaknesses, and we will find our inner artist together. Are you planning to step into the acting industry? Have you tried auditioning but you do not have the resources to get recognized? From Headshots to CV to showreels and self tapes. It can be overwhelming, but do not worry. We all have been there. This club aim to ease your journey into the acting and theatre industry. UTC is seeking usher volunteers to assist on the show day. clubs.name: University of Toronto Students’ Union (UTSU)
clubs.description: The University of Toronto Students’ Union (UTSU) represents approximately 40,000 full-time undergraduate, professional faculty students on the St. George campus of the University of Toronto. Each College and Faculty, which UTSU represents, elects representatives from the members of their constituency to sit on our Board. Their number of students enrolled during the previous academic year determines the number of seats per constituency. The council is composed of a seven-member executive and a Board of Directors, all of which represent the constituencies from which they were elected. UTSU’s mission is to serve and represent the full-time undergraduate students at the University of Toronto in order to ensure the best possible undergraduate experience. While academics play an important role in the life of a student, UTSU strongly believes in a balance between both academics and personal development. The representation UTSU provides strives to ensure the strongest possible voice for the full-time undergraduates at the University of Toronto. All services UTSU provides must then respond to the wishes of the constituents it represents. We wish to acknowledge this land on which the University of Toronto operates. clubs.description: The University of Toronto Supply Chain and Intelligence Management (UTSCIM) Club brings together students passionate about revolutionizing global commerce through the integration of supply chain management, artificial intelligence (AI), and machine learning (ML). Our club provides a platform for members to explore real-world challenges in supply chain optimization using advanced AI and ML techniques, bridging the gap between academic theory and practical application. By joining UTSCIM, members gain access to hands-on workshops, case studies, and projects that focus on solving contemporary supply chain problems. Members can also engage with industry professionals and peers through networking events, fostering a collaborative environment that encourages innovation, critical thinking, and professional growth. Whether you’re looking to enhance your knowledge, develop new skills, or make industry connections, UTSCIM offers the resources and community to help you succeed. Join us in exploring the future of supply chain management, AI, and ML, and become part of a diverse group dedicated to unlocking the full potential of these fields for a more efficient and innovative world. clubs.name: University of Toronto Taekwondo Student Organization
clubs.description: TaeKwonDo has its roots in Korea but it has evolved into the quick paced martial art that is practiced globally. UTTO is a fantastic way for those interested in the art of Taekwondo to get together and practice their skills, perfect their technique and master new kicks. We hold classes for all skill levels starting at an introductory level and going all the way for classes held for competitive sparring. During the regular Fall/Winter semester, the club has approximately 50 beginner/intermediate students and 20 competitive team members. The U of T Taekwondo Team is an unofficial club team that has had a lot of success at tournaments both in and out of province. In April 2009, U of T clinched the Ontario Universities Taekwondo Competitive League (OUTCL) inter-collegiate tournament, coming in first place overall. In November 2009, the U of T Taekwondo Team competed in Master Chong’s World Class Taekwondo Tournament at Buffalo State College in Buffalo, N.Y., UTTO’s first international competition. The competitive team has competed in OUTCL tournaments and many local tournaments organised by the Ontario Taekwondo Association in the past years. In 2016, UTTO organised the University League, a chance for students to spar students from other university clubs. UTTO is not only about learning and practising Taekwondo. UTTO organises numerous social events throughout the year, including pub nights, board breaking seminar, and our annual trip to Hart House Farm as a way to get to know fellow UTTO members and create a mini-UTTO family. For our latest updates, please visit our Instagram page. We wish to acknowledge this land on which the University of Toronto operates. clubs.name: University of Toronto Toastmasters Student Chapter
clubs.description: University of Toronto Toastmasters (UTT) is a club that is aimed at creating a supportive environment where anyone can improve their public speaking and leadership skills. The club began in 2004, beginning life as University of Toronto Engineering Toastmasters. Since then, UTT has expanded to help hundreds of students and professionals alike rise above their fears, realize their dreams, grow into incredible speakers, and live as stronger leaders. Currently, our club meets for regular meetings once a week, where members present and give feedback on prepared and impromptu speeches. We also plan special events several times per semester, for instance, promotional open houses and speaking competitions. All members enjoy the benefits of the various opportunities to speak during meetings and meet new people. Members also have the chance to pay for access to Toastmasters International’s Pathways, an education programme with different “paths” for members to hone different aspects of their public speaking. The club is very proud of the environment it creates, one that is supportive and positive, with peer evaluations focused on collective growth. clubs.name: University of Toronto Vietnamese Students’ Association (UTVSA)
clubs.description: The University of Toronto Vietnamese Students’ Association (UTVSA) is a non-profit organization founded in 1981. Since then, the UTVSA has sought to promote and preserve Vietnamese language and culture by encouraging dialogue between University of Toronto students and the Vietnamese community. In collaboration with Vietnamese Students’ Unions from other Universities around Ontario, UTVSA has actively worked to better the University experience for Vietnamese students by providing a strong supportive social network, organized social and academic based events, and a forum for discussion within a vibrant Vietnamese community. Regardless of whatever changes may come with varying social context, demographic, members and leaders, UTVSA’s fundamental goal has always remained the same. Through networking events, self-improvement workshops, cultural workshops, fundraisers, and many socials, this is how UTVSA hopes to achieve it. They are a place of open arms, welcoming anyone to reach out and connect. Regardless of who or where someone is from, UTVSA aims to ignite a spark in them an appreciation for Vietnamese culture, and to continue fueling the flames in those already with a burning passion for all that is Vietnam. Hội Sinh Viên Việt Nam Đại Học Toronto (UTVSA) là một tổ chức phi lợi nhuận được thành lập vào năm 1981. Từ khi bắt đầu, hội đã đề ra mục tiêu gìn giữ và quảng bá văn hoá và ngôn ngữ Việt bằng cách khuyến khích sự trao đổi giữa sinh viên Đại học Toronto và cộng đồng Việt Nam. Thông qua sự cộng tác với các hội sinh viên Việt Nam khác trên toàn tỉnh bang Ontario, UTVSA đã và đang tích cực hoạt động nhằm mang lại những trải nghiệm tốt hơn cho sinh viên Việt Nam. Hội thường xuyên tổ chức những sự kiện và hoạt động giao lưu văn hoá, tạo điều kiện cho các thành viên kết nối với nhau, cũng như những buổi tư vấn về học thuật hay kỹ năng sống nhằm hỗ trợ sinh viên. Bên cạnh đó UTVSA cũng là nơi để mọi người cùng nhau ăn mừng trong những dịp lễ quan trọng của Việt Nam. Mục đích hoạt động của UTVSA đã, đang và sẽ không thay đổi theo bất kỳ sự thay đổi nào trong xã hội và chính trị, trong bất cứ hoàn cảnh, thời điểm nào và dưới sự điều hành của bất kỳ ai. Hội luôn chào đón tất cả mọi người đến giao lưu và sẵn sàng hỗ trợ khi cần. Bất kể bạn là ai hay đến từ đâu, UTVSA hy vọng sẽ nhóm lên trong bạn niềm yêu thích và sự cảm kích đối vời nền văn hoá Việt Nam. clubs.name: UofT Floral Club (UTFC)
clubs.description:
Welcome to the University of Toronto Floral Club, where we cultivate connections through our shared appreciation of nature’s most beautiful blooms. Our society brings together students, faculty, and staff who share a passion for flowers in all their forms. We offer a unique blend of artistic expression through flower arrangement workshops and outdoor adventures exploring Ontario’s diverse flora. Our flower arrangement sessions provide hands-on experience in both traditional and contemporary styling techniques, guided by experienced instructors. Throughout the academic year, we organize guided hiking excursions to discover native wildflowers in their natural habitats, from the vibrant trilliums of spring to the golden asters of autumn. These outings combine botanical education with physical activity and photography opportunities, making them perfect for both nature enthusiasts and casual observers. Beyond the aesthetic appeal, our society serves as a bridge between cultures, celebrating floral traditions from around the world. Members learn about the cultural significance of different flowers and arrangement styles, from Japanese ikebana to European cottage gardens. This cross-cultural exchange creates meaningful connections among our diverse university community. We welcome members of all skill levels and backgrounds. Whether you’re an experienced gardener or simply appreciate the beauty of flowers, you’ll find a welcoming community here. Join us to develop new skills, make lasting friendships, and contribute to the vibrant tapestry of campus life at the University of Toronto. Regular activities include:
– Flower arrangement workshops
– Seasonal hiking expeditions Transform your university experience by becoming part of this flourishing community where creativity blooms and friendships grow naturally. Our mission and mandate revolve around harnessing the potential of open geospatial data to benefit humanitarian efforts, support underrepresented communities, our everyday lives and the environment. Our missions are to 1) empower marginalized and underrepresented communities by putting them on the map—literally and figuratively and 2) harness the power of citizen science in our everyday lives Our club thrives on teamwork. Members collaborate to update existing maps, fill in data gaps for underserved regions, and collect data on environmental biodiversity and street-level imagery. By leveraging platforms like iNaturalist and Mapillary, we contribute not only to humanitarian causes but also to environmental conservation and urban planning efforts. We foster a supportive, diverse community of students and volunteers who are passionate about geospatial data’s transformative power. Our mapping assists the Red Cross and Médecins Sans Frontières to address key global challenges, from improving healthcare access to enhancing disaster preparedness. Whether you are a seasoned car enthusiast or a newcomer to the field, we welcome you to join us. Here, you can meet like-minded friends, and we can all help and support each other with any car-related issues. Our club is more than just a group for discussing cars; we also regularly organize various car-related activities and meetups, such as auto shows, technical exchanges, and more. Through these events, you will not only deepen your understanding of car culture but also enhance your practical skills in operation and maintenance. Join us to rev up your passion for cars and expand your automotive world! We wish to acknowledge this land on which the University of Toronto operates. clubs.name: UTM Fight for Hope (UTMFFH)
clubs.description:
‘Fight for Hope’ is to raise awareness of a variety of illnesses, both known and unknown, including cancer, diabetes, cystic fibrosis, hepatitis A/B, and many others. In order to improve public knowledge, we aim to fight health care misinformation. To enhance the social lives of students, we want to plan entertaining fundraising activities. Most importantly, our goal is to raise money to support charitable organizations that fight against these diseases.
We aim to achieve this through fundraising events, such as bake sales, movie nights, exam de-stressor workshops, game nights, etc. Furthermore, we will also host informational sessions where we educate students on a specific disease. clubs.name: UTM Karting
clubs.description: The purpose of the UTM Karting group is to foster a vibrant community of motorsports enthusiasts at the university. The group’s primary objectives are: Organize and host engaging events that allow students to connect over their shared love of racing and Formula 1. This includes hosting regular F1 watch parties where members can come together to enjoy the races and discuss the latest developments in the sport. Coordinate the annual UTM GP, a campus-wide go-karting event that provides an opportunity for students to experience the thrill of competitive racing in a safe and supervised environment. This event aims to promote sportsmanship, teamwork, and personal growth through the lens of motorsports. Facilitate off-campus karting outings, enabling members to hone their driving skills and explore their passion for racing in a professional setting. These outings serve to build skill and healthy competition among the group and offer a fun, adrenaline-filled activity outside of the classroom. By fostering an inclusive and welcoming community, the UTM Karting group strives to create a space where students from all backgrounds can come together, share their enthusiasm for motorsports, and engage in exciting activities that complement their academic pursuits. clubs.name: UTM MedLife
clubs.description: MEDLIFE is an international organization that works closely with low-income communities in an attempt to tackle various medical, educational, and developmental problems. UTM MEDLIFE is a chapter of MEDLIFE available at the University of Toronto Mississauga campus. We work closely with MEDLIFE headquarters to coordinate projects in South American and African communities abroad, specifically, we develop various fundraising campaigns and dedicate the funds to various topics. This year, our campaign is called Ignite the Light!. The campaign is dedicated to focused on providing education in our chosen communities with infrastructure for kindergartens and schools. UTM MEDLIFE also coordinates Service Learning Trips in which club members can travel abroad once a year to assist in pop-up clinics in low-income communities and are provided the opportunity to shadow doctors in the chosen destination of travel. Club members are encouraged to join important meetings and events to learn more about how they can help in local and international communities! clubs.name: UTM Moot Court Team (UTM MCT)
clubs.description:
Hi there!

Welcome to UTM’s newest pre-law club, the UTM Moot Court Team (UTM MCT)! This is an exciting and unprecedented opportunity at UTM, designed for students who are passionate about law, public speaking, advocacy and critical thinking! So, what is Moot Court?
Moot Court is a simulated court proceeding where participants argue legal cases before a panel of judges. Here you’ll explore creating sound legal arguments, advancing your legal reasoning, develop persuasive arguments, and sharpen your advocacy skills. Why join the UTM Moot Court Team?
Here’s what you can expect by joining: Whether you dream of becoming a lawyer, exploring the world of law, or simply building transferable skills, UTM MCT is the perfect platform to challenge yourself and grow!
